Introduction

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is a member of the Herpesviridae family, which contains large, enveloped DNA viruses capable of lifelong latent infection and reactivation.  Serologic evidence of CMV exposure in adults is widespread (>60% in developed regions; >90% in developing regions).  Transmission can occur via transplacental, neonatal, close contact, genital, and iatrogenic routes.  Most acute infections in immunocompetent individuals are asymptomatic, but a minority (~10%) develop a mononucleosis-like illness.  Severe complications can arise in fetal infection and in those with significant immunocompromise (eg, AIDS, organ transplantation).

Risk factors



Most transmissions occur due to contact with an individual who has a primary or reactivated infection; latent infections are associated with transient viral shedding and carry a lower risk of transmission.



  • Perinatal (primary/active infection in mother):
    • Fetal infection due to transplacental spread.
    • Neonatal infection due to exposure to cervical/vaginal secretions or breast milk.
  • Close contact (saliva):
    • Daycare (toddlers, staff).
    • Households (family members).
  • Sexual contact:
    • Multiple sexual partners.
    • History of sexually transmitted infection.
  • Blood/tissue exposure:
    • Blood transfusion.
    • Organ transplantation from seropositive donor.
  • Reactivation risk factors:
    • AIDS (CD4 <50/mm3).
    • Immunosuppressive therapy (eg, high-dose corticosteroids, chemotherapy).
    • Organ/hematopoietic stem cell transplantation.

Pathophysiology

Acute infection



CMV has tropism for a wide range of host tissue, including epithelial/endothelial cells, smooth muscle cells, fibroblasts, and monocytes.  Binding and entry are mediated by viral surface glycoproteins (glycoprotein B, glycoprotein H-L).  Once the virus is inside the cell, viral genes are expressed in a temporally controlled manner, as follows:



  • Immediate-early genes (first 4 hours) upregulate viral promoters and alter host cell signaling to make it more conducive to viral replication.
  • Delayed early genes (4-48 hours) enable CMV genomic replication.
  • Late genes (subsequent days) code for viral structural and assembly proteins.


The virus uses host RNA polymerase for viral gene transcription and viral DNA polymerase to replicate its genome.  Viral DNA replication occurs in a specialized compartment in the host cell nucleus, which generates the classic histopathologic finding of CMV: a large basophilic nuclear (owl's eye) inclusion body (

image 1
).  Once replication is complete, the virus lyses the host cell (a property shared by many Herpesviridae).  This process typically takes several days to complete.



Although acute infections are largely asymptomatic (>90%), infected individuals typically develop viremia and viral shedding in body fluids (saliva, urine, genital secretions).  Most patients also develop transient immunosuppression due to viral infection of dendritic cells, which impairs T-cell stimulation and antigen processing.

Latent infection



The virus establishes a lifelong latent infection in myeloid cells.  Like other herpesviruses, the CMV genome is maintained as a circular episome outside of the host chromosome (but still in the nucleus).



Periodic viral shedding may occur during latent infection, but viremia and symptoms are rare.  Because latent infection is largely contained by the cytotoxic T-cell response, significant stress (eg, critical illness) or immunocompromise (eg, AIDS, immunosuppressive medications) can lead to reactivation and symptomatic disease.

Immune evasion



CMV is efficient at immune evasion due to the following viral-mediated mechanisms:



  • Down-modulating class I and II MHC molecules on antigen presenting cells.
  • Producing homologues that interact with receptors on immune cells to downregulate the immune response.
  • Producing Fc-binding glycoproteins that compete for host Fc-receptors on immune cells, thereby reducing the efficacy of antibody mediated-immunity.

Pathology



Histopathologic examination (

image 2
) of CMV-affected tissues shows:



  • Cytomegaly with prominent intranuclear inclusions (owl's eyes), representing foci of genomic replication.
  • Smaller inclusions seen in the cytoplasm, representing assembling virions.
  • Focal necrosis with minimal inflammation, representing the cytotoxic effect (lysing cells).


CMV can attack any organ, but disease burden is often greatest in glandular organs (parenchymal epithelial cells), brain (neurons), lungs (macrophages, epithelial/endothelial cells), and kidneys (tubular epithelial and glomerular endothelial cells).

Clinical manifestations

Immunocompetent individuals



Most cases are asymptomatic, but a minority (~10%) develop CMV mononucleosis.  This syndrome closely resembles Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) mononucleosis.  Both tend to cause a few weeks of malaise, fatigue, fever, chills, and headache; however, CMV mononucleosis differs from EBV mononucleosis in the following ways:



  • Diffuse/cervical lymphadenopathy is less common.
  • Pharyngitis/exudative tonsillopharyngitis is less common.
  • Splenomegaly is less common,
  • Heterophile antibody (monospot) negative:  Patients with a mononucleosis syndrome who have negative heterophile antibody testing should be evaluated for CMV.


Patients also typically have lymphocytosis with >50% mononuclear cells on complete blood count and >10% atypical lymphocytes on peripheral blood smear.  In immunocompetent hosts, CMV rarely causes organ-specific complications (eg, colitis, encephalitis, Guillain-BarrÃ© syndrome, pneumonia, retinitis).

Immunocompromised individuals



Patients with severe immunocompromise (eg, AIDS, organ transplantation) are at risk for complications of CMV infection due to reactivation of latent virus or (less commonly) acute infection.  Manifestations are broadly divided into 2 categories, as follows:



  • CMV syndrome is marked by viremia with no manifestations of end-organ involvement.  Patients may develop fever, malaise, fatigue, and nonspecific laboratory abnormalities (eg, leukopenia/neutropenia, atypical lymphocytosis, transaminitis, thrombocytopenia).
  • CMV disease is marked by end-organ damage, which may include:
    • CMV retinitis, causing full-thickness retinal necrosis with surrounding edema that is eventually replaced by thin, atrophic scar tissue.  This tends to move in a centrifugal fashion along the blood vessels and appears on fundoscopy as yellow-white, granular lesions.  Manifestations include blurring/loss of central vision, floaters, scotoma (blind areas), and/or photopsia (flashing lights).  Retinal detachment can occur.  Most cases are unilateral at presentation.
    • CMV colitis, marked by mucosal inflammation, vascular endothelial cell damage, and local tissue necrosis.  Patients usually develop low-grade fever, anorexia, malaise, abdominal pain, and weight loss.  Periodic, explosive watery diarrhea is common.  Hemorrhage and perforation can occur.  Endoscopy typically reveals punctate/superficial erosions, deep ulcerations, or necrotizing colitis.
    • CMV esophagitis, usually presenting with odynophagia, fever, nausea, and burning substernal chest pain.  Multiple ulcers at the lower esophageal sphincter can often be visualized on endoscopy; they tend to be deep, longitudinal, and linear.
    • CMV pneumonitis, which typically causes low-grade fever, dyspnea, non-productive cough, and impaired pulmonary function.  Chest x-ray can reveal a range of findings, including patchy or diffuse ground glass opacities, patchy consolidation, or small nodules.

Congenital CMV



Most congenital infections cause no symptoms, but ~10% of fetal infections are associated with symptomatic disease, which may include:



  • Symptomatic infection in the neonate:  Common findings include petechiae, jaundice, small size for gestational age, microcephaly, lethargy/hypotonia, hepatosplenomegaly, and laboratory abnormalities (eg, elevated transaminases, thrombocytopenia, elevated bilirubin).  Neuroimaging may show intracranial calcifications, lenticulostriate vasculopathy, white matter disease, and/or ventriculomegaly.
  • Sensorineural hearing loss:  CMV is the leading cause of nonheritable sensorineural hearing loss.  This may be evident at birth but often does not become clinically apparent until infancy or early childhood.
  • Late complications:  Late complications are most common in neonates who are symptomatic at birth.  Common complications (other than sensorineural hearing loss) include intellectual impairments, strabismus, microcephaly, seizures, cerebral palsy, and autism spectrum disorder.

Diagnosis



Definitive diagnosis of CMV infection generally requires PCR, antigen assays, culture, or histopathologic examination.  Although many of these tests can be used for diagnosis of acute infection or viremia, the presence of end-organ disease (CMV disease) typically requires tissue biopsy with histopathologic confirmation.  The diagnostic tests are as follows:



  • PCR is used for screening those at risk for CMV, diagnosing active infection, and monitoring response to therapy (quantitative PCR).  PCR is highly sensitive; samples can be taken from blood, cerebrospinal fluid, or tissue.
  • Antigen assays detect CMV proteins (pp65) in peripheral blood leukocytes using fluorescent-labeled monoclonal antibodies.  It allows for rapid, direct detection of CMV infection.  Sensitivity is reduced in the setting of neutropenia.
  • Histopathologic examination of tissue biopsy or washings (eg, bronchoalveolar lavage) can provide evidence of end-organ infection (CMV disease).  Infected host cells are enlarged and have basophilic intranuclear (owl's eye) and cytoplasmic inclusions; immunohistochemical staining can increase sensitivity.
  • Culture of specimens in human fibroblast media can provide definitive diagnosis, but CMV grows slowly, and sensitivity can be low.
  • Serology provides indirect evidence of CMV infection.  It is often used to determine whether a patient is at risk for CMV reactivation when preparing for organ transplantation or immunosuppressive medications (the absence of CMV IgG indicates very low likelihood of latent infection).  Recent or acute infection is generally marked by positive CMV-specific IgM and a fourfold (or more) increase in CMV-specific IgG in titers taken 2-4 weeks apart.

Differential diagnosis

CMV mononucleosis



  • EBV mononucleosis often causes fever, malaise, and atypical lymphocytosis, but patients are more likely to have pharyngitis, cervical/diffuse lymphadenopathy, and splenomegaly.  In addition, most cases are marked by a positive heterophile antibody test.

CMV esophagitis



  • Candida esophagitis typically presents with odynophagia, but patients frequently have discrete retrosternal pain and thrush (oropharyngeal Candida).  Endoscopy will show white mucosal plaque-like lesions; biopsy will reveal yeast and hyphae invading mucosal epithelial cells.
  • Herpes simplex virus (HSV) esophagitis often causes odynophagia/dysphagia, fever, and retrosternal pain.  Endoscopy usually reveals volcano-like, well-circumscribed ulcers with normal intervening mucosa; this is in contrast to CMV, which typically causes linear, longitudinal, deep ulcers.

CMV colitis



  • Acute ischemic colitis typically presents with crampy abdominal pain, focal abdominal tenderness, and tenesmus.  Hematochezia may be present.  Endoscopy typically reveals edematous, erythematous, friable mucosa interspersed with pale areas; cyanotic mucosa with scattered hemorrhagic erosions/ulcerations can occur.

CMV retinitis



  • Benign cotton wool spots, which are often caused by HIV, hypertension, and diabetes mellitus, can appear similar to the retinal lesions seen in CMV retinitis.  However, CMV lesions will progress toward the fovea slowly over the course of serial examinations.
  • Progressive ocular retinal necrosis (PORN) is an aggressive retinitis caused by varicella zoster virus (primarily) or HSV.  It typically presents with multifocal, necrotizing, peripheral retinal lesions; unlike CMV, it tends to spare the retinal vasculature.

Congenital CMV



  • Congenital toxoplasmosis can cause a wide range of manifestations in the neonate, particularly chorioretinitis, intracranial calcifications, hydrocephalus, thrombocytopenia, jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, and/or lymphadenopathy.  Comparative features are shown in this table (

Management

Immunocompetent individuals



  • CMV mononucleosis:
    • Supportive therapy generally sufficient, as most cases self-limited.
    • Antiviral therapy (eg, ganciclovir, valganciclovir, foscarnet) not recommended for most cases but may be required for those with protracted mononucleosis symptoms or in the rare case of organ-specific complications.
  • Pregnancy:
    • Antiviral therapy (valacyclovir) generally warranted for primary CMV infection during early pregnancy to reduce risk of fetal infection.

Immunocompromised individuals



  • CMV syndrome (viremia with no end-organ manifestations):
    • Reduction in immunosuppression (when possible).
    • Antiviral therapy (ganciclovir, valganciclovir) for symptomatic patients.
  • CMV disease:
    • Reduction in immunosuppression (when possible).
    • Antiviral therapy:
      • First line: ganciclovir (IV) for severe disease and valganciclovir (oral) for mild/moderate disease.
      • Alternates: foscarnet (IV), cidofovir (IV), or maribavir (oral) for resistant or refractory CMV.

Congenital CMV



  • IV ganciclovir or valganciclovir for symptomatic cases (improved long-term neurodevelopmental and audiologic outcomes).
  • Antiviral therapy not indicated in asymptomatic cases.
  • Role of antiviral therapy in infants with CMV-related isolated hearing loss uncertain.

Complications



Complications of acute or latent infection are rare in immunocompetent individuals.  Those with immunocompromise are at much greater risk for morbidity due to end-organ disease.  Congenital CMV is associated with neurodevelopmental and neurologic (eg, sensorineural hearing loss) impairment.  Risk of reactivation is greatest in those with critical illness (eg, mechanical ventilation in the intensive care unit), advanced age (immunosenescence), or immunocompromise.

Prognosis



Immunocompetent patients generally have no sequelae of acute or latent infection.  Patients with immunocompromise are at greater risk for significant morbidity from end-organ disease.  Risk is related to immune status at diagnosis, early recognition/treatment, and ability to improve immune status by reducing immunosuppressive medication (eg, organ transplantation) or providing antiretroviral therapy (AIDS).

Summary



CMV is a member of the Herpesviridae family, a group of double-stranded DNA viruses that establish lifelong latent infection and are capable of reactivating.  Evidence of serologic CMV exposure is widespread in adults.  Most immunocompetent individuals experience no symptoms of acute infection; however, a minority (~10%) develop a self-limited mononucleosis syndrome.  In contrast, those with immunosuppression (eg, AIDS, organ transplantation) are at high risk for complications (eg, retinitis, colitis, esophagitis, pneumonitis) from acute or reactivated infection.  Congenital infection can also cause complications (eg, neurodevelopmental impairment).  The diagnosis is typically established by PCR, antigen testing, serology, and/or histopathology.  Antiviral therapy (eg, ganciclovir, valganciclovir) is generally required for those with end-organ disease or symptomatic neonatal infection.
